comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content:
A true yarn.

I was ashore in Trincomalee once in the fifties and there, by the side of the road was a Fakir snake charmer with his snakes, his snake baskets, his 'for effect' flute and his staked out mongoose.
All he had on was a skimpy loin cloth, a skimpier scraggly beard and boy did he look the part?..... straight down out of the hills!
The snakes were cobras and of course I assumed that they had had the poison sacs removed, I mean, come on, who on earth would let a British sailor wear a fully armed cobra around his neck so he could have his picture taken with it?
Yes, that's what I did, let him drape a snake around my neck while I passed my camera to a chum to get a picture.
THEN things started to go not quite as planned.
The snake was around my neck when it twisted its head around till it was arched and it was looking me right in the eyes, so close that I swear I got cross eyed looking at it.  Then I saw that the snakes right eye was hanging right down out of the socket and dangling on it's 'cheek'.....the mongoose must have had a go at it.
It was about then that my legs started to shake, my knees started to knock and I started to think of my mother and how much she would miss me!
The Fakir must have realised what was going to happen because he suddenly grabbed the snakes tail and whipped it away from my face just as it struck!
I had a beard and as the beasts fangs snapped shut in the beard as it was dragged clear it pulled a big chunk of my beard out with it.....that bloody hurt as well!
Now I can tell you the following true facts, your knees DO knock, you DO go grey with fear and after something like this your chums DO have to lead you away and buy you a pint!
Oh! and after all that my dingbat of a mate had'nt even got a picture, he could'nt figure out how to work the bloody camera!
Did I go back and try again?..........Yeah.......riiiiggghhht!

comment.author: 57878783@N07
comment._content: Wow, look at that skin he's wearing. A serious warrior!

comment.author: 34918130@N07
comment._content: This is a really rare Photo.  Amazing how they looked .

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: @Camilo3600 I'm afraid we can't pin down any of the dates in this collection. We're hoping to be able to add this information over time (with the help of Flickr users).

comment.author: 95082748@N04
comment._content: We have been looking closely and the man in this photo is probably also the Man in the trilby hat also in this collection.  We have been wondering if he might be Martini Maccomo!  There is a striking resemblance - this might be a younger image.

comment.author: 95082748@N04
comment._content: Maccomo was called a Serpent Charmer in 1861! When with Manders! However if it is a Bostock & Wombwell picture then I'm not aware of Maccomo working there!

comment.author: 95082748@N04
comment._content: There was also another Maccomo late 1800's  Think that this photo seems to be more of that vintage. Therefore unlikely to be  original Maccomo. Tricky isn't it, I'm off to read EH Bostock's memoires now!
